About

Publications

CV


Hosted on GitHub Pages — Theme by orderedlist

I’m a fifth year PhD student in the Cognitive Science department at Johns Hopkins University, working with Dr. Paul Smolensky and Dr. Kyle Rawlins. My main areas of interest are computational semantics/pragmatics, and generalization in humans and machine learning models. I use computational and experimental linguistic methodologies to explore these areas. Please refer to the Publications section to find out more.

As of October 2020, 60% of me is at JHU dissertating, and 40% of me is at Google as a student researcher working on presuppositions for question-answering, both remotely :)

Updates

  • Sep 2020: “COGS: A Compositional Generalization Challenge Based on Semantic Interpretation” with Tal Linzen was accepted to EMNLP 2020! Preprint coming soon.
  • Sep 2020: Gave an invited presentation at the Microsoft Research AI Breakthroughs Workshop. Check out our poster!
  • Aug 2020: At Google for another few months as a student researcher, continuing my work on presuppositions for question-answering.
  • July 2020: Presented our paper Implicit Discourse Relation Classification: We Need to Talk About Evaluation at ACL 2020. This was based on my internship project at IBM Research.
  • Summer 2020: At Google as a research intern with Deepak Ramachandran and Ellie Pavlick!
  • Jan 2020: Presented a poster on demonstratives with Sadhwi Srinivas & Kyle Rawlins at LSA 2020.
  • Dec 2019: Presented a paper titled Compositionality as Directional Consistency in Sequential Neural Networks at the Compositionality Workshop at NeurIPS 2019.
